sen.j: 向日市（むこうし）は、京都府の市。
sen.e: Muko City is a city in Kyoto Prefecture.
Muko City is a city in Kyoto Prefecture.
Muko City is a city in Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 地理
sen.e: Geography
Geography
Geography

sen.j: 京都盆地の南西端に位置し、西方には小塩山をはじめとする西山連峰を望み、市外東方には桂川 (淀川水系)が流れる。
sen.e: Muko City is located on the southwestern edge of the Kyoto Basin; to the west lies the Nishiyama Mountain Range including Mount Oshio-yama, and to the east outside the city flows the Katsura-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River System).

Muko City is located on the southwestern edge of the Kyoto Basin; to the west lies the Nishiyama Mountain Range including Mount Oshio-yama, and to the east outside the city flows the Katsura-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River System).

Muko City is located on the southwestern edge of the Kyoto Basin; to the west lies the Nishiyama Mountain Range including Mt. Oshio, and to the east outside the city flows the Katsura-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River system).

sen.j: このため、全般に北西方向が高地に南西方向が低地となる平坦な地形となっている。
sen.e: As a result, the city has overall a flat terrain with a plateau on its northwest part and a lowland on its southwest part.
As a result, the city consists overall of flat terrain with a plateau on its northwest part and a lowland on its southwest part.
As a result, the city consists overall of flat terrain with a plateau on its northwest part and a lowland on its southwest part.

sen.j: そこを東海道本線・阪急京都本線が貫く。
sen.e: The Tokaido Main Line and the Hankyu Kyoto Main Line run across the city.
The Tokaido Main Line and the Hankyu Kyoto Main Line run across the city.
The Tokaido Main Line and the Hankyu Kyoto Main Line run across the city.

sen.j: 長岡京市、大山崎町とともにタケノコの産地として著名。
sen.e: Muko City as well as Nagaokakyo City and Oyamazaki-cho is famous for producing bamboo shoots.
Muko City as well as Nagaokakyo City and Oyamazaki-cho is famous for producing bamboo shoots.
Muko City as well as Nagaokakyo City and Oyamazaki-cho are famous for producing bamboo shoots.

sen.j: 京野菜の千両ナスやミズナにポインセチアなどの花き栽培も盛んである。
sen.e: Traditional Kyoto vegetables such as potherb mustard and senryo eggplant as well as flowers such as poinsettia are widely grown.
Traditional Kyoto vegetables such as potherb mustard and senryo eggplant as well as flowers such as poinsettia are widely grown.
Traditional Kyoto vegetables such as potherb mustard and senryo eggplant as well as flowers such as poinsettia are widely grown.

sen.j: 深田川：秦川勝が造った潅漑用水路（西ノ岡用水、寺戸用水とも呼ばれる）
sen.e: Fukada-gawa River: an irrigation canal built by HATA no Kawakatsu (also called Nishino-oka Yosui canal or Terado Yosui canal)
Fukada-gawa River: an irrigation canal built by HATA no Kawakatsu (also called Nishino-oka Yosui canal or Terado Yosui canal)

sen.j: 山 山岳はないが、西部の丘陵地に竹林を形成
sen.e: Mountain: there are no mountains but bamboo groves are found on the hillside on the west of the city.
Mountain: there are no mountains but bamboo groves are found on the hillside on the west of the city.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 古くは山城国乙訓郡に属し、長岡京が設置された。
sen.e: The area of the present-day Muko City belonged to Otokuni-no-kori (Otokuni-gun), Yamashiro Province, and Nagaoka-kyo (imperial capital) was once established.
The area of the present-day Muko City belonged to Otokuni-no-kori (Otokuni-gun), Yamashiro Province, and once housed Nagaoka-kyo (imperial capital).
The area of the present-day Muko City belonged to Otokuni-no-kori (Otokuni-gun), Yamashiro Province, and once housed Nagaoka-kyo (imperial capital).

sen.j: 市域からは大極殿跡が発掘されている。
sen.e: The Daigoku-den (imperial palace) site has been unearthed in the city.
The Daigoku-den (imperial palace) site has been unearthed in the city.
The Daigoku-den (imperial palace) site has been unearthed in the city.

sen.j: 長岡京が平安京に移されてのちはその後背地として農業を産業の中心とした。
sen.e: After the capital was transferred from Nagaoka-kyo to Heian-kyo, agriculture became the main industry in the area as a backland for the new capital.
After the capital was transferred from Nagaoka-kyo to Heian-kyo, agriculture became the main industry in the area as a backland for the new capital.
After the capital was transferred from Nagaoka-kyo to Heian-kyo, agriculture became the main industry in the area as a backland for the new capital.

sen.j: 古くから乙訓郡の中心地であり、現在も郡役所の名残である京都府乙訓総合庁舎、向日町警察署が設置されている。
sen.e: The area has been the center of Otokuni-gun since old times; currently, the Kyoto Prefectural general office of Otokuni-gun, a remnant of the district office, and the Mukomachi Police Station are placed in Muko City.

The area has been the center of Otokuni-gun since old times; currently, the Kyoto Prefectural general office of Otokuni-gun, a remnant of the district office, and the Mukomachi Police Station are located in Muko City.

The area has been the center of Otokuni-gun since old times; currently, the Kyoto Prefectural general office of Otokuni-gun, a remnant of the district office, and the Mukomachi Police Station are located in Muko City.

sen.j: 他にもJR向日町駅のように、「向日町」の旧町名を市制施行後の今でも地名のように使っている施設などがある（町が市へ昇格した際に「町」も市名に含めた例は新潟県十日町市、長野県大町市などが挙げられる）。
sen.e: Additionally, even after the shisei (grant of city status) was implemented, some facilities such as the JR Mukomachi Station have used the old town name 'Muko-machi' for their names as it were still a name of the place; there are cases such as Tokamachi City, Niigata Prefecture and Omachi City, Nagano Prefecture that included even the part 'machi' (cho, or town) in their city names when towns were given city status.

Additionally, even after the shisei (grant of city status) was implemented, some facilities such as the JR Mukomachi Station have used the old town name 'Muko-machi' for their names as if it were still a name of the place; there are cases such as Tokamachi City, Niigata Prefecture and Omachi City, Nagano Prefecture that included even the part 'machi' (cho, or town) in their city names when towns were given city status.

Additionally, even after the shisei (grant of city status) was implemented, some facilities such as the JR Mukomachi Station have used the old town name 'Muko-machi' for their names as if it were still a name of the place; there are cases such as Tokamachi City, Niigata Prefecture and Omachi City, Nagano Prefecture that included even the part 'machi' (cho, or town) in their city names when towns were given city status.

sen.j: なお、町制時の町名のよみは「むこうちょう」であったが、現在「向日町」と名のつく施設などは、「むこうまち」と読むものがほとんどである。
sen.e: When the chosei (grant of township) was implemented, the town was named 'Muko-cho;' however, the old town name Muko-cho is now generally read as 'Muko-machi' when it is used for the name of a facility.

When the chosei (grant of township) was implemented, the town was named 'Muko-cho;' however, the old town name Muko-cho is now generally read as 'Muko-machi' when it is used for the name of a facility.

When the chosei (grant of township) was implemented, the town was named 'Muko-cho;' however, the old town name Muko-cho is now generally read as 'Muko-machi' when it is used for the name of a facility.

sen.j: 1889年（明治22年）4月1日の町村制施行以降、昭和・平成の大合併の時期を含めて、一度も合併を経験していない、全国でも数少ない自治体のひとつである。
sen.e: Muko City is one of the rare municipalities in Japan that have never merged with any other municipality since the enactment of the chosonsei (Town and Village System Law) on April 1, 1889, including the Great Mergers of the Showa and Heisei periods.

Muko City is one of the rare municipalities in Japan that never merged with any other municipality since the enactment of the chosonsei (Town and Village System Law) on April 1, 1889, including the Great Mergers of the Showa and Heisei periods.

Muko City is one of the rare municipalities in Japan that never merged with any other municipality since the enactment of the chosonsei (Town and Village System Law) on April 1, 1889, including the Great Mergers of the Showa and Heisei periods.

sen.j: 1889年（明治22年）、向日町が周辺5村（物集女、寺戸、森本、鶏冠井、上植野）と合併。
sen.e: In 1889, Muko-cho merged with its neighboring five villages of Mozume, Terado, Morimoto, Kaide and Kamiueno.
In 1889, Muko-cho merged with its neighboring five villages of Mozume, Terado, Morimoto, Kaide and Kamiueno.
1889: Muko-cho merged with its neighboring five villages of Mozume, Terado, Morimoto, Kaide and Kamiueno.

sen.j: 1972年（昭和47年）10月1日、市制施行。
sen.e: On October 1, 1972, the shisei (grant of city status) was implemented.
On October 1, 1972, the shisei (grant of city status) was implemented.
October 1, 1972: The shisei (grant of city status) was implemented.

sen.j: 京都市、長岡京市 向日市はその周囲のうち、北西東を京都市と接し、南を長岡京市と接する。
sen.e: Kyoto City and Nagaokakyo City: Muko City is adjoined to Kyoto city on the east, west and north, and to Nagaokakyo City on the south.
Kyoto City and Nagaokakyo City: Muko City is adjoined to Kyoto city on the east, west and north, and to Nagaokakyo City on the south.

sen.j: なお、東側は旧乙訓郡久世村 (京都府)であり、西側は旧乙訓郡大原野村であったが、京都市への編入により、旧向日町が乙訓郡から京都市に突出する形で残ったものである。
sen.e: Incidentally, the city used to be adjoined with the former Kuse-mura, Otokuni-gun on the west and Oharano-mura Otokuni-gun on the east, but since Kyoto City absorbed the two villages, formerly Muko-cho has remained as if it jutted out into Kyoto City from Otokuni-gun.

Incidentally, the city used to be adjoined with the former Kuse-mura, Otokuni-gun on the west and Oharano-mura Otokuni-gun on the east, but since Kyoto City absorbed the two villages, formerly Muko-cho has remained as if it jutted out into Kyoto City from Otokuni-gun.

sen.j: また、京都市と向日市は市街地が連続しており、現地に行ってみても一目で市境を判別するのは困難である。
sen.e: The downtown area in Kyoto City and Muko City is connected, making it difficult to determine the border at a glance on site.
The downtown areas of Kyoto City and Muko City are connected, making it difficult to easily determine the border.

sen.j: 東向日駅または西向日駅（市北端部では洛西口駅）から乗車し、烏丸駅で京都市営地下鉄烏丸線（四条駅 (京都市営地下鉄)）に乗り換え、丸太町駅 (京都市営地下鉄)で下車、北西方向へ徒歩10分である。
sen.e: Take the Hankyu Kyoto Line at Higashimuko Station or Nishimuko Station (or Rakusaiguchi Station from the northern edge of the city), transfer to the Kyoto City Subway Karasuma Line at Karasuma Station (or Shijo Station), get off at Marutamachi Station, and walk northwest for 10 minutes.

Take the Hankyu Kyoto Line at Higashimuko Station or Nishimuko Station (or Rakusaiguchi Station from the northern edge of the city), transfer to the Kyoto City Subway Karasuma Line at Karasuma Station (or Shijo Station), get off at Marutamachi Station, and walk northwest for 10 minutes.

Muko-jinja Shrine: it was built in 718 and its main shrine was built in the sangensha nagare-zukuri (architecture of three-bay wide structure with a gable roof).
